rsbNotes.title: Eccl 7:1
rsbNotes.text: 7:1 day of death. For the godly, death is “far better” (Phil. 1:23) because they are with Christ.

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 7:2, 4
rsbNotes.text: 7:2, 4 house of mourning. A funeral provides an indispensable perspective on the universally terminal condition.

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 7:7
rsbNotes.text: 7:7 oppression . . . a bribe. These common experiences may threaten to destabilize an otherwise good spiritual condition (4:1–3).

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 7:9
rsbNotes.text: 7:9 anger lodges. If unquenched, the anger ignited by life’s frustrations leads to folly.

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 7:11–12
rsbNotes.text: 7:11, 12 Wisdom . . . preserves the life. True wisdom gives benefits in this life (contrast 8:8) and that to come. Christ is the redemptive wisdom of God (1 Cor. 1:30), making wisdom accessible to sinners.

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 7:13–18
rsbNotes.text: 7:13–18 Both human illusions of perfection in this life and the abandonment of oneself to wickedness have God for an adversary.

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 7:13
rsbNotes.text: 7:13 who can make straight. God’s decrees cannot be reversed. The curse of Gen. 3 will not be annulled until the consummation.

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 7:14
rsbNotes.text:
7:14 prosperity . . . adversity. God decrees the one as the other.

man may not find out anything. The future is unknown.

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 7:15
rsbNotes.text: 7:15 righteous . . . wicked. The question implied by this observation is formulated in Jer. 12:1 (“Why does the way of the wicked prosper?”) and handled at more length in Ps. 37 and 73.

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 7:16–17
rsbNotes.text: 7:16, 17 Be not overly righteous . . . overly wicked. Pride can masquerade as righteousness, even in small things; on the other hand, there is an impulse to lawlessness that goes beyond everyday standards of life.

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 7:18
rsbNotes.text: 7:18 this . . . from that. Right knowledge of God delivers those who possess it from destructive excesses of self-righteousness and wickedness.

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 7:19
rsbNotes.text: 7:19 gives strength to the wise. Wisdom is powerful and encouraging.

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 7:20
rsbNotes.text: 7:20 not a righteous man. All are guilty before God (Ps. 14:3; 53:3).

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 7:22
rsbNotes.text: 7:22 many times. We are all multiple offenders in God’s sight.

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 7:24
rsbNotes.text: 7:24 who can find it out. No one can fully comprehend God’s understanding; it is qualitatively different from human knowledge (8:16, 17; 1 Cor. 2:11).

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 7:29
rsbNotes.text: 7:29 made man upright. God created Adam morally good (Gen. 1:31), but all sin (Rom. 3:23; 5:12). See “The Fall” at Gen. 3:6.

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 8:5–6
rsbNotes.text: 8:5, 6 proper time and the just way. The truly wise seek and commonly find the proper time for every action (3:1–8).

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 8:8
rsbNotes.text: 8:8 power. We cannot control death or evil, but Christ has this power (John 10:18; Rev. 1:18).

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 8:9
rsbNotes.text: 8:9 to his hurt. Probably this means to hurt the one ruled. Solomon has seen how the irresponsible use of God-given authority injures people (Rom. 13:3, 4).

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 8:10–13
rsbNotes.text: 8:10–13 Though inequities abound in human societies, as experienced in civil disorders of our own time, God will nevertheless settle all accounts justly.

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 8:14
rsbNotes.text: 8:14 on earth. In this life the righteous and wicked do not necessarily get what they deserve.

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 8:15
rsbNotes.text: 8:15 commend. In the face of injustice, people are nevertheless to rejoice in this life. Solomon’s mode of expression is pessimistic, but in the immediate context he mentions that life is the gift of God.

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 8:17
rsbNotes.text:
8:17 all the work of God. See 7:13; 11:5.

cannot find out. God’s work cannot be fathomed.

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 9:1–10
rsbNotes.text: 9:1–10 Solomon commands the enjoyment of life, despite the reality of death.

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 9:1
rsbNotes.text:
9:1 in the hand of God. God sovereignly controls the affairs of both the righteous and wicked.

love or hate. Presently both “good” and “bad” things happen to righteous and wicked people according to God’s inscrutable design (Matt. 5:44, 45; Luke 13:1–5).

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 9:3
rsbNotes.text: 9:3 full of evil. People are totally depraved, that is, corrupt in every aspect (Gen. 6:5).

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 9:10
rsbNotes.text: 9:10 with your might. Like v. 4, this verse emphasizes the necessity of dealing with life as we find it.

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 9:11–12
rsbNotes.text: 9:11, 12 chance. Solomon describes people as victims of inscrutable or even cruel chance. Nevertheless, the believer understands that God orders events in unexpected ways.

rsbNotes.title: Eccl 9:16
rsbNotes.text: 9:16 despised. Solomon sees that wisdom is indeed better than might—but that the wise are not appreciated.
